The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

On February 7, 2014, EVC’s President Yong and SJCC's Interim President Breland received a letter from the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) regarding the actions of the Commission at its meetings of January 8-10, 2014.   The Commission based its actions on their review of the colleges Midterm Reports and affirmed accreditation for both colleges.  The letter, nevertheless, requested that a follow up report be submitted by March 31, 2014, to address specific compliance with Standard III.A.1c that reads as follows:
 “Faculty and others directly responsible for student progress toward achieving stated student learning outcomes have, as a component of their evaluation, effectiveness in producing those learning outcomes.”
 Leadership from both colleges and the District Office met to discuss the letter and identify the necessary steps to comply with the Commission’s request.  In addition, a team from both colleges, including Presidents Yong and Breland and Vice Presidents Aytch and Graham, met with Commission staff to ensure clear understanding of the type of evidence and documentation necessary to satisfy the requirements.   This item includes two types of documents that meet the standard; the first, addresses faculty and the second, includes “others directly responsible for student progress (i.e. academic administrators)" as follows:
 1. Faculty - a three-year pilot program between the FA, AFT 6157 (Union) and the San Jose Evergreen Community College District (District) regarding the recommendations of the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) that Student Learning Outcomes (SLO’s) be a component of faculty evaluations.  As the District and Union are not currently involved in negotiations, this pilot program is not a contract proposal. The three-year pilot program is an interim measure designed for the limited purposes of addressing the ACCJC’s requirements until the issues addressed in the pilot program are negotiated between the District and the Union.  As part of this pilot program, it is agreed that no data derived from SLO assessments shall ever be used to evaluate faculty performance. The District and the Union agree to the pilot program being in effect from Fall 2014 through Spring 2017 to coincide with the faculty evaluation cycle.
	 
2. Academic Administrators - Board Approval of Consent Agenda  Item F-7 of April 8, 2014 – “Revisions to Academic Administrator Job Descriptions and Performance Appraisal Form to Address Responsibility for the Systematic Assessment of Student Progress and Learning Outcomes” and the proposed evaluation form.  The positions included in this process are the following:
 
Dean of Business and Workforce Development.pdf
Dean of Counseling & Matriculation (SJCC).
Dean of Humanities and Social Science.
Dean of Language Arts.
Dean of Math & Science (SJCC).
Dean of Math, Science and Engineering (EVC)
Dean of Nursing and Allied Health.
Dean of Social Sciences, Humanities, Arts, & Physical Education
Dean of Student Success
Vice President of Academic Affairs
Vice President of Student Affairs
Director of Kinesiology and Athletics

items.item_details: At the April 8, 2014, Governing Board Meeting, President Lease, on behalf of the Board Governance Task Force, reviewed a draft document of the Board Ends Policies and Governance Principles document that was revised at the March 31, 2014, meeting of the Task Force. Mr. Randy Parent, legal counsel from Liebert Cassidy and Whitmore, had recommended that the policies, with the exception of ends policies, be changed to principles, and that Executive Limitations be changed to Executive Requirements. He also recommended a change in the order of the principles and eliminated some principles that were more administrative in nature and that were already contained in Board Policies Chapter Two. Although the Board accepted the recommendations of the Task Force, it was determined that further work needed to be done on the ends policies. Therefore, the Board Governance Task Force met, along with Chancellor Cepeda and executive administrative assistant Joy Pace, on April 15, 2014, to provide additional ends policies to the Board governance document. These additional ends policies have been included on the attached draft, which is being presented to the Board as a first reading.

As a part of their Policy Action Agenda, the Association of Community College Trustees has collaborated with over 150 community college leaders to create the Governance Institute for Student Success.  The purpose of the institute is to advance the policy action agenda:  The Policy Action Agenda: Encourages governing boards to develop student success policies; Reaffirms a commitment to access and equity; Calls upon governing boards to take action.  The Institute took place on March 14 through 16 at Chabot College and was attended by Chancellor Cepeda, Trustee Myra Cruz, Trustee Maria Fuentes, and Trustee Wendy Ho.  
	 
The purpose of this information item is to present briefly about the lessons learned from the Institute as well as touch on recommended action steps that the Board can take to continue to monitor the student success agenda of the District.  Trustees Cruz, Fuentes, and Ho will present a summary dedicated to three key areas of impact: Culture Change; Measurement and Data; and Partnerships with K-12 schools.

items.item_details:
Background
	 
Service learning has a long history in postsecondary education that is also linked to a national policy focused on service and volunteerism. Some of the most well-known initiatives include VISTA, AmericCorps and the Peace Corps to name a few.
	 
Service learning combines community service with classroom instruction, focusing on critical, reflective thinking as well as personal and civic responsibility. Service learning programs involve students in activities that address local needs while developing their academic skills and commitment to their community. Service learning has a positive impact on student learning outcomes, civic engagement, and retention.
	 
Beginning in 1994, the American Association of Community Colleges promoted the value of service learning to the 1,200 associate degree-granting institutions in the U.S. According to three AACC national surveys, two-thirds of all community colleges offer service learning in their curricular programs.
	 
In 1996 Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College established Service Learning and Public Service Programs. Since that time, both colleges have maintained the core mission of the program while developing slightly different approaches regarding the organization and delivery of services.
	 
This item focuses on concerns raised by the Service Learning Faculty Coordinator at Evergreen Valley College in a memorandum dated October 17, 2013, entitled: "EVC ServLearn Program, a Safety and Liability Risk to Students and District." This memorandum was addressed to the Chancellor and copied to the Board of Trustees, the leadership at EVC and the Faculty Association.
	 
Subsequent Steps
	 
November 26, 2013 - Meeting between Chancellor and Faculty Coordinator to review the October 17 memorandum, seek clarification and determine the educational needs and risk factors associated with the continuation of the program in its current state.
	 
December 2, 2013 - Meeting between Chancellor and College President to request prompt action be taken given the risk factor raised regarding student safety and to ensure that issues associated with the successful operation of the program would be addressed.
	 
It is important to note that at no time has there been a directive to "end" the program. The direction has been to review, rectify concerns and, most important of all, to ensure student safety. Whenever the element of risk is raised by a faculty or staff member, this act places the district/college "on notice" requiring prompt action.
	 
This item is brought in response to public comments presented at the April 8, 2013, Governing Board Meeting. The report will inform the board on the current status of the program and the program evaluation currently in place to address program concerns. It is expected that corrective actions be identified and implemented within the framework of resources available to ensure effective program delivery.

The Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges, Western Association of Schools and Colleges (ACCJC) accredits community colleges and other associate degree granting institutions in the Western region of the U.S. The ACCJC is one of seven regional accrediting commissions. Standards for accreditation are reviewed and revised on a regular basis.  The current accrediting standards were adopted in June 2002, revised in June 2012 and edited in November 2012.
 
The latest revision of the standards placed particular attention on research, planning, continuous quality improvement, responsibilities of the governing board and a focus on teaching, learning and Student Learning Outcomes (SLOs).  It is expected that as of 2016, colleges will write their self-study using the revised standards.
	 
This item focuses on Standard IV: Leadership and Governance and the implications of proposed changes on the role, functions and responsibilities of the Board of Trustees.
